summary: This document is a chain of emails from February 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office staff regarding travel approval requests for witness interviews related to the Epstein investigation (case 2018R01618). It details planned trips to Pensacola, Florida, and references prior trips to locations including Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, and Stockholm, Sweden, for the purpose of conducting interviews.

connections.description: Both are mentioned as part of the investigative team traveling together for witness interviews in the Epstein case.

events.title: Witness Interview in Pensacola
events.description: Planned travel by SDNY prosecutors to Pensacola, Florida, to interview a witness for the Epstein investigation, requiring flight and hotel bookings and a conference room reservation.

events.title: Witness Interview near Stockholm
events.description: Reference to a prior planned trip for the team to travel to near Stockholm, Sweden, for an interview, indicating an international dimension to the investigation.

events.title: Witness Interview in Los Angeles
events.description: Reference to a prior planned trip to Los Angeles for an interview or interviews related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Interview in West Palm Beach
events.description: Reference to a prior planned trip for an interview in West Palm Beach, Florida, involving S and another colleague.

events.title: Victim Interview in Los Angeles
events.description: Reference to a prior planned trip for a victim interview in Los Angeles, involving S, M, and/or another colleague.

keyFacts: The document references the ongoing federal investigation 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as 'an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
Prosecutors from the SDNY were conducting witness interviews in multiple domestic and international locations (Florida, California, Sweden) as part of the investigation in 2019-2020.
Travel requests frequently included approval to reserve hotel conference rooms for conducting the interviews.
The email chain shows logistical planning and approval processes within the U.S. Attorney's Office for investigative travel.
The primary correspondent is identified as an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, though the name is abbreviated.
